MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Improvements to Mainline Rail Networks.

Speaker.P: I thank you, Sir, for allowing me to raise this important topic and with your permission, I wish to share my time with my constituency colleague, Deputy Penrose.
Is that agreed? Agreed.

About three weeks ago the Government launched the National Development Plan creating great expectations for the future of our country. Indeed, the opening sentence on page 7 says that the National Development Plan is a plan for employment. Today, that statement is being contradicted. Already, the aspirations of the plan are not being met because of the lack of matching funds and jobs are being lost. Infrastructural developments are outlined in Chapter IX and it is proposed to expend £275 million on improving mainline rail networks. This includes track renewal, new signalling systems and the purchase of modern rolling stock. Among the lines to be improved is the Dublin-Belfast and the Dublin-Mullingar-Sligo lines. A programme of track renewal is already under way and there is great expectations that the new rolling stock, promised for mid-1994 will improve the computer service between Dublin and Mullingar. As the Minister knows, an improved service will attract more customers and that, in turn, will bring more badly needed revenue to Iarnród Eireann.

MainHeading.P: However, these great plans have, unfortunately, been derailed because, from today, the programme of track renewal on the Dublin-Belfast and on the Dublin-Mullingar-Sligo lines will stop. Iarnród Éireann is making 31 employees redundant because it cannot provide the matching funds to continue this work. Ten of these married employees work from Mullingar and they and single men will now go on the dole and draw money from Government resources. The other 21 workers operate from Drogheda. The track renewal needs to be done and the work will be done, if not this year next year or the year after, it is merely being postponed. The funding from Europe is available but the matching Irish funds are not. I call on the Minister to make these relatively small amounts of money available to Iarnród Éireann to keep these men at work; to keep the development plan on the rails; to provide a better commuter service on the Dublin-Mullingar line and to improve the rail network throughout the country.

Speaker.P: I thank my constituency colleague for sharing his time. I join in expressing my concern at the news that ten workers were given notice that they were being laid off. They were engaged in relaying new track on the Dublin-Mullingar-Sligo railway line and this involved the continuing CWR track renewal programme. As Deputy McGrath points out, £275 million is provided in the National Development Plan for a major investment programme in the rail network over the next five years. We all know that the upgrading of the Dublin-Sligo line and the provision of new track, new signalling and new rolling stock needs to be carried out. Why delay the process? It is vital work required to ensure that the public who use public transport do so in the greatest of comfort. It is important to provide a comfortable commuter service to entice the public to utilise it.

I see this as important for the provision of employment. This is especially important in a rural area and for those who live in the area around Mullingar. Ten men will go on to the live register and this is demoralising so near Christmas. Some of the workers are married. They were laid off in October 1992 and re-employed on 4 January 1993, a break of two months. In view of the fact that the work is urgently required I appeal to the Minister to make available to Iarnród Eireann the necessary matching funds to allow the necessary work to continue.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I note the concerns expressed by Deputies McGrath and Penrose. I should point out first that staffing levels, recruitment of temporary staff and related issues in the CIE group and its subsidiaries are the responsibility of the boards and management involved. It would be inappropriate for me as Minister to become involved in any way in such matters and I have no intention of doing so.

For the information of the Deputies, however, I understand that Iarnród Éireann's annual track renewal programme involves the recruitment of seasonal employees every year. These employees are laid off as the individual elements of that year's track renewal programme are completed in mid-autumn. The track renewal programme is carried out on this basis primarily because the work concerned is outdoors and has to avail of maximum daylight and favourable weather conditions. The position in CIE in this regard is similar to other sectors, including agriculture and construction, which feature significant seasonal employment. The lay-off of temporary workers in Iarnród Éireann is not, therefore, related to the level of Exchequer finance available to Iarnród Éireann.

By way of background, I should point out that the Exchequer grant to CIE for 1993 is £108.4 million. Given the constraints on the Exchequer, this very substantial amount illustrates beyond any question this Government's commitment to public transport. I should also mention that the public Capital Programme for 1993 provides for capital expenditure of up to £97 million by the CIE group on a number of major capital and track renewal projects including:—
—upgrading of the Dublin-Belfast line; provision of commuter services on the south west rail corridor;
—new railcars and locomotives which are due for delivery early next year; and new signalling equipment.

MainHeading.P: Both the Dublin-Belfast and south west Dublin projects are receiving significant EC financial support.

The Deputies will be aware that the National Development Plan which was published recently and submitted to the European Commission includes provision for an EC assisted investment programme of £185 million in the period 1994-99 on the upgrading of the mainline railway network. In addition, a further £90 million approximately of unco-financed investment is proposed over the period of the plan subject to the resources available to CIE. The investment programme, which covers all the major lines on the inter-urban mainline railway network which includes the Dublin-Sligo and Dublin-Belfast lines will include expenditure on track renewal, new signalling systems and the provision of modern rolling stock.

Finalisation of the investment programme, as regards specific expenditures on individual lines, will follow from consultations over the coming months between my Department, CIE and the European Commission. I am sure there will be more seasonal employment next year and perhaps these people will avail of that opportunity at that stage.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Extension of DART Service.

Speaker.P: I thank you, Sir, for allowing me to raise this matter on the Adjournment. It was stated in the National Development Plan that the DART would be extended to Greystones, County Wicklow. While this may seem a minor detail it is a matter of grave concern to the large population in north Wicklow, particularly those living in Greystones, in view of the Minister's response to my parliamentary question of Tuesday, 2 November, when he stated that the issue was being examined only in the context of the draft operational programme on transport. The natural expectation was that the proposal would be included in the national plan, particularly as a consequence of its inclusion in the Dublin Transportation Initiative interim report which recommended that £28.6 million should be spent on upgrading suburban rail services and specifically included a figure of £6 million to extend the DART service to Greystones. However, the National Development Plan specifies that only £20 million will be spent in that area. There is a shortfall of £8.6 million between the two figures and that is a matter of concern for the people in Greystones. There was no firm commitment in the Minister's reply in regard to its placing in the operational programme. He stated that the Dublin Transportation Initiative report would be substancially implemented by 1999. In view of the shortfall, what will be omitted? That is what the people of Greystones are concerned about.

It is worth mentioning that the area covered by the report includes 50 per cent of the population of County Wicklow. Yet, the only recommendation to invest in public transport in the country appears in danger of being ignored while all the money may be spent on public transport in County Dublin. If this is the case it would be a total negation of the Dublin Transportation Initiative report which recognises that, to relieve Dublin's traffic congestion, it is necessary to provide a good public transport service beyond County Dublin. The Dublin Transportation Initiative report recommends that the DART service should be extended to Greystones, the only definitive DART extension recommended in any report. The managing director of Iarnród Éireann considers the DART the most logical and cost effective solution to the transport problem of Greystones. That argument is further reinforced by the fact that an extension of the DART service to Greystones will pay its capital cost within 12 years through increased usage. That would make it the most financially viable rail investment set out in the national plan.

MainHeading.P: We are not talking about simply improving the service to Greystones but about upgrading it to a level which pertained in the past. During the years 1983 to 1989 nine direct trains travelled each day from Greystones to Pearse Street station, that has been reduced to one train per day. In ten years the population of Greystones has increased by 50 per cent, but the train service has been almost wiped out. When Greystones had its service withdrawn other commuter rail services such as those to Malahide, Maynooth and, more recently, Clondalkin, were vastly improved as a result of substantial Government investment. I assure the Minister that the people of Greystones would not take to the streets — as they did last year — unless they believe in what they are doing, the case they have presented during the past number of years is a strong one. The DART service is the most effective solution to the transport needs of Greystones, it is also the most cost effective solution because far more people would use a direct and reliable service than a diesel shuttle service. The extra users would more than pay for the extra capital cost involved.

The proposal outlined by the Dublin Transportation Initiative group would provide a park and ride site in Greystones which would service people from Delgany, Kilcoole, Kilpedder and Newcastle and relieve traffic congestion in Bray and in the city of Dublin. That proposal has been welcomed by the Dublin traders.

Will the Minister make a clear commitment to the people of Greystones to extend the DART to their town? Strong arguments were advanced in favour of this and the Dublin Transportation Initiative group was seen as the body to advise the Minister on the best way forward. No greater signal could have been received by the Minister from DTI than its clear and unequivocal support for the extension of the DART service to Greystones. What we and the people of Greystones now need is similar unequivocal support and direction by the Minister to provide an extension of the DART service to Greystones.

Speaker.P: In my reply to the question mentioned by the Deputy, I indicated that the National Development Plan includes provision for an EC assisted investment programme of £220 million of which up to £200 million expenditure is proposed for the development of a light rail transit system for Dublin. A further £20 million has been included in the plan for other important public transport projects, including the development of public transport interchange facilities, integrated ticketing and the upgrading of suburban rail services, including the possible extension of the DART to Greystones and Malahide. These issues are being further evaluated at present under the ongoing Dublin Transportation Initiative process and the outcome will be reflected in the final report of the DTI which is expected shortly. It would not be appropriate for me to pre-empt the final report of the Dublin Transportation Initiative in relation to specific transportation options which may be recommended for Greystones.

In general terms the overall cost of the main priorities which have been outlined above will exceed the level of funding available. Accordingly, it is essential that the expenditure of £20 million to non-LRT work is carefully allocated to the most effective projects in overall public transport terms. In this context, I am aware of the concerns of residents in Greystones concerning the extension of DART to Greystones.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Demolition of Dublin Georgian Buildings.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Speaker.P: The buildings to which this matter refers are two buildings side by side at the bottom of Harcourt Street on the corner of St. Stephen's Green in Dublin. In construction terms, both buildings date from the 1780s and are four storey Georgian buildings of significant architectural importance. The roof of each building has lost its slating and neither of the buildings, for some peculiar reason, was given list one status in Dublin Corporation's plan. In any self-respecting city in Western Europe neither of those buildings would be demolished. In no country in Western Europe would a building dating from the 18th century be demolished in similar circumstances. The buildings look shabby because they have no slating — but I do not believe that is the result of strong winds — and because their windows have been blocked up with cement blocks. However, because of clandestine photography it is evident that inside those buildings there is significant treasure of late 18th century plaster work which is part of our architectural heritage and which will be destroyed if the buildings are knocked down.

The local government planning and development code dates from 1963 and is fundamentally an engineers' charter. It is not a conservation code. Although it provides that county councils and local authorities such as urban district councils and county boroughs can list buildings in their areas as conservation buildings, it does not provide any means to ensure that such buildings are preserved. Anybody owning a Georgian building in this city is free to remove its slates and there is nothing a local authority can do to stop that person. That is the law. There is no positive duty to conserve any part of our architectural heritage. If a building is dangerous or derelict, even though it is listed for conservation, the State can do nothing positive to oblige the owner of the building to conserve it. Ownership has its duties as well as its rights and that is written on the plinth of the Drummond statue in City Hall. In a modern urban environment and in this day and age we should recognise that buildings are part of our heritage and are not the free and disposable property of their owners to destroy them at will.

MainHeading.P: In making a submission to An Bord Pleanála on this issue a local representative in whose constituency the buildings are situated must now pay a charge of £30 for making a submission as to why the buildings should not be destroyed. I am not charged £30 for writing to the corporation when the original decision is made, or if I write to a Minister, or for bringing it up in this House, where doubtless I am using far more State resources than I would by writing to An Bord Pleanála. I sent a one page letter to An Bord Pleanála asking it to consider the architectural and historical significance of this building and the fact that it is the birth place of Sir Edward Carson. The letter was returned to me with a note saying that it would be considered if I had the good grace to add a £30 cheque to it and send it back to An Bord Pleanála. That is wrong. As a public representative I am entitled to represent my constituents. I am entitled to make a public statement where it matters to a body charged by the public to decide these matters. I am entitled as a public representative to have my views heard. I went through the process of election and having won an election it confers on me the right to have my views heard on issues such as that. If public representation means anything it means that.

If it is the view of the Department of Finance that I am not entitled to make a submission without paying a fee I would ask the Minister to indicate to the House what measures the Government has in mind to reimburse Members for representations made not out of private interest but in the public interest to a body such as this. I have never heard of a public representative being charged for giving evidence at a licensing session in a District Court or for giving evidence in support of any proposition in any court of the land. I have never heard of a public representative being charged for sending a letter to a corporation who decide these matters in the first instance. How can it be that a public representative should be charged money for making a representation in relation to a matter before An Bord Pleanála when it is done out of public duty?

Speaker.P: Recently a number of people, including the Rev. Ian Paisley, expressed serious concern about the threatened demolition of No. 4 Harcourt Street. The reason is that Mr. Edward Carson was born there. He is remembered for his role in the creation of a Northern Protestant State, often referred to in those times as being Carsonian. Mr Carson has left an indelible mark on our history and his place of birth should be preserved. At least it would be seen as an expression of tolerance and political maturity by people in the Republic.

Little has been said about No. 3 Harcourt Street, where Mr. George Fitzmaurice, the great Kerry dramatist, lived for a number of years until his death on 12 May 1963. He was one of the pioneer dramatists of the Abbey Theatre, a contemporary of Synge, Yeats and Lady Gregory and he played a major part in the Irish literacy revival in the early part of the century. According to Mr. Fintan O'Toole, the literacy critic of The Irish Times, Fitzmaurice was arguably the most imaginative Irish writer of this century. No less a critic than Irving Wardle wrote:
Fitzmaurice is obviously a remarkable writer, one of the great originals among folk dramatists and an innovator of more than national interest.

Mr. George Fitzmaurice was born in Bedford House near Listowel in January 1877. His father was the local Church of Ireland parson, who had married a local Catholic girl, a thing unheard of at that time. Their sons, including George, were brought up as Protestants while the daughters were brought up as Catholics. Every Sunday morning Parson Fitzmaurice would drop his wife and daughters at the local Catholic church and then proceed to his own church to conduct his service. That says much about the level of tolerance, acceptance and ecumenism which existed in north Kerry at that time. This broadmindedness survived and is reflected in several ways in the north Kerry community.
Fintan O'Toole said:

George Fitzmaurice's importance and his curse was that when he started to write he was able to create a synthesis of Protestantism and Catholicism to make a nonsense of the great opposition of Irish culture.

MainHeading.P: Fitzmaurice's works are based on material which he took from the peasant culture in north Kerry, especially the parish of Duagh. The language, the folklore, the social realities reflected in his plays are those of the Catholic community. His first play “The country Dressmaker” was produced in the Abbey Theatre in 1907 and was very well received. His next two plays “The Pie Dish” and “The Magic Glasses” were also produced at the Abbey. “The Magic Glasses” was also produced in London as part of a small selection of plays taken to London by the Abbey. These included plays by Yeats and Lady Gregory. The critics in London placed his play ahead of the plays of both Yeats and Lady Gregory. He has a number of other plays, including the “Dandy Dolls”, “The Linnaun Shee”, “Twixt the Giltenans and the Carmodys” and so on.

George Fitzmaurice became an employee of the Congested Districts Board of the Land Commission in November 1901 and later served in the British Army in Flanders from 1914 to 1918. He retired from the Civil Service in 1943 and led a secluded life on a small pension until his death in May 1963 at No. 3 Harcourt Street.

This week An Taisce expressed concern about Nos. 3 and 4 Harcourt Street. It fears that they will be demolished unless preventive action is taken immediately. Demolition can be prevented if a preservation order is placed on the buildings by the Office of Public Works. Mr. Fintan O'Toole, in a most enlightening article in The Irish Times today, said:

By all means, let us preserve Carson's house. It marks our history and speaks to us of what for good or ill we have built. But it is even more important, in this present darkness, to preserve that other haunted house of hope next door, that house of quiet despair where unseen amidst the silence, a great Protestant Catholic defeated by that same history, dared to put on paper his mad tales, subverting oppositions and celebrating the stubborn, perverse, defiant imagination of humanity. For if that house falls, then not only Carson's house, but the whole streetscape of political civilisation on this island goes with it.
I appeal to the Minister to mandate the Office of Public Works to immediately, place a preservation order on these two buildings.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. Gallagher, Donegal South-West) Minister of State at the Department of Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. Gallagher, Donegal South-West)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. Gallagher,
Speaker.P: Donegal South-West): I thank Deputies McDowell and Deenihan for their contributions. Nos. 3 and 4 Harcourt St. are Georgian buildings which are in a bad state of repair and have not been occupied for some time.

Application was made for planning permission for the six storey office development over a basement carpark, involving the demolition of houses Nos. 3 and 4 Harcourt St. This application was refused by Dublin Corporation on 10 September 1993 on the grounds that the building was too high and out of scale and was contrary to land use zoning of the 1991 Dublin City Development plan in that the office content was excessive. This decision was appealed to an Bord Pleanála and a decision on the appeal is pending, but must be decided by 10 February 1994. Anyone wishing to make observations may do so in writing by 10 November 1993 on payment of a fee of £30.

The Office of Public Works are considering the appropriateness of using the National Monuments Acts to afford protection to these houses. In this connection they are arranging to have the houses inspected under section 8 of the National Monuments (Amendment) Act, 1987.

MainHeading.P: As the Deputies mentioned, both of these buildings have historical associations, No. 3 having been the residence of playwright George Fitzmaurice — like Deputy Deenihan, a Kerryman and a distant relation of his — and No.4 having been the birthplace of Sir Edward Carson. While these would be consideration in any decision relating to the preservation of these houses, regard must be had to other factors such as their structural condition and the cost involved. The Office of Public Works expects to have the inspection of Nos. 3 and 4 carried out in the near future and we must await that report.

With regard to the matter of An Bord Pleanála fee, which was raised by Deputy McDowell, I understand from my colleague, the Minister for the Environment, that he has been advised by the board that it gives due and courteous consideration, within the statutory provision governing the appeals process, to all representations received from public all representatives. If a public representative writes to an Bord Pleanála merely making an inquiry as to the position on an appeal or indicating general support for or opposition to an appeal, the board takes the view that this is not a submission within the meaning of planning law and that no fee is payable. However, where representations from a public representative raise new and substantive issues in relation to an appeal the board has to consider whether these are such as to constitute formal submissions or observations which would be governed by the provisions of the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1992, and the fees requirements. The Minister would expect that the bulk of correspondence received by the board from public representatives would not come within the category and that no fee would be payable. It might also be pointed out that no fee would be payable where a public representative appears at an oral hearing on behalf of a party to an appeal or on behalf of any person who has made formal written submissions to the board about the appeal.

The payment of a fee to the board by a public representative only arises therefore where the public representative makes formal and substantive submissions or observations. It is not considered that the charging of a fee in these circumstances is unreasonable and I understand from my colleague, the Minister for the Environment, that there are no proposals to alter the position.
The Dáil adjourned at 9.5 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Thursday, 4 November 1993.

Qst.askee: Minister for Equality and Law Reform

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Legislation on Discrimination.

Qst.askee: Minister for Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: his response, as Minister with overall responsibility for the travelling community, to recent events in Glenamaddy, County Galway involving clashes between local residents and travellers; when it is intended to introduce legislation to outlaw discrimination against travellers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor) Mervyn Taylor
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor)
Speaker.P: The Task Force on the Travelling Community, which was set up by me on foot of a commitment contained in the Programme for a Partnership Government, has set up a sub-committee to examine the discrimination experienced by travellers and to make recommendations aimed at promoting mutual understanding and respect between the travelling community and the settled community. At the same time, I have been keeping in touch with events in relation to travellers and with the situation in Glenamaddy as it developed. I arranged for my programme manager and a senior official from my Department to attend the court case which preceded the events of Monday 11 October.

MainHeading.P: As I indicated in my press statement of 12 October, I was extremely concerned at the reports of the disturbances in Glenamaddy. I condemn ouright any actions of physical violence as being totally inappropriate to the norms of a civilised community. The fundamental principle at issue is the right of each and every citizen of Ireland to access to public facilities on a basis of equality, whether a member of the travelling community or not.

The Deputy will be aware that I have already indicated on numerous occasions I am bringing forward legislation to extend legal redress against discrimination in relation both to the employment and non-employment areas. The preparation of the proposed legislation on employment equality is progressing and I expect to introduce the legislation next year.

I hope to have the legislation in respect of non-employment areas passed in 1994. This legislation will prohibit discrimination in the provision of goods, facilities and services, including recreational facilities and service, entertainment, transport and professional services, accommodation and the disposal of property.

The grounds on which discrimination will be prohibited are those set out in the Programme for Government and include sex, marital or parental status, sexual orientation, religion, age, handicap, race, colour, nationality, or national or ethnic origins, or membership of the travelling community.
Discrimination by a publican against travellers will be prohibited. However, discrimination on grounds other than those referred to above, such as mis-behaviour, will be lawful.

Qst.askee: Minister for Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that all his directives or requests to other Government Departments regarding matters of equality or law reform are, or have been, complied with; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor) Mervyn Taylor
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor)
Speaker.P: I have no power to issue directives to other Government Departments regarding matters of equality or law reform. All Government Departments are expected to comply with statutory provisions and Government policy.

Issues relating to equality or law reform arise periodically and are usually dealt with as necessary in ongoing consultations at official level between Government Departments. Should major issues arise which cannot be resolved at official level or in discussion with my ministerial colleagues, I would present proposals to the Government for decision.
I also have a duty to monitor developments in the equality and law reform areas coming within my ministerial remit. I am generally satisfied with the co-operation received from other Departments.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Commission on Disability.

Qst.askee: Minister for Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: if he will publish a programme of action in respect of disabled persons; and if he will ensure that such a programme will take account of the needs of special schools for people with a disability.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Equality and Law and Reform (Mr. Taylor) Minister for Equality and Law and Reform (Mr. Taylor)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Equality and Law and Reform (Mr. Taylor)
Speaker.P: On 5 May 1993, the Taoiseach and I met with representatives of the Forum of People with Disabilities and agreed to establish a Commission on Disability. An undertaking was also given that the terms of reference of the Commission would be drawn up within three to six months by my Department in consultation with representatives of people with disability and other relevant Government Departments.

My Department subsequently placed advertisements in the major newspapers inviting written submissions from interested groups and individuals on the terms of reference of the Commission on Disability. Eighty-four submissions were received in response to this invitation.

In September, 1993, I recruited a temporary consultant with a wide-ranging expertise in issues relating to people with disability to assist me in assessing these submissions and to advise me on the establishment of the Commission.

MainHeading.P: On 5 October, 1993 I announced my intention of appointing Mr. Justice Feargus Flood as Chairperson of the Commission. I have no doubt that, with a person of the calibre of Justice Flood as Chairperson, the Commission will undertake its task with a high degree of professionalism and competence.
I am at present finalising my proposals for the establishment of the Commission and I intend to submit them for approval by the Government shortly.

The Commission will have wide-ranging terms of reference and the needs of special schools will be among the matters which will be considered by it. In the circumstances, I believe that it would not be prudent to attempt to pre-empt its findings in that respect.

As I have already indicated on numerous occasions I am bringing forward legislation to extend legal redress against discrimination in relation both to the employment and non-employment areas. The preparation of the proposed legislation on employment equality is progressing and I expect to introduce the legislation next year.

I hope to have the legislation in respect of non-employment areas passed in 1994. This legislation will prohibit discrimination in the provision of goods, facilities and services, including recreational facilities and services, entertainment, transport and professional services, accommodation and the disposal of property.

The grounds on which discrimination will be prohibited are those set out in the Programme for Government and include sex, marital or parental status, sexual orientation, religion, age, handicap, race, colour, nationally, or national or ethnic origins, or membership of the travelling community.
It is intended that the person who is discriminated against will be able to take action to vindicate his or her rights.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Nuclear Arms Industry.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs
Qst.Quest: Ireland's position with our counterparts in the EC regarding the nuclear arms industry; the countries who support or reject the nuclear non-proliferation treaty; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring) Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring)
Speaker.P: The use of nuclear energy for weapons purposes does not come within the scope of the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM). The matter is thus outside the Community competence. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), of which Ireland and its partners are members, has the twin purposes of promoting the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, and ensuring that nuclear activities are not used to further any military purpose.

Ireland has always been a strong advocate of nuclear non-proliferation. We were one of the original proponents of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT), and the first to sign and ratify it in 1968. At present almost 160 states are parties to the Treaty but about 30 states have not yet acceded to it. Of the States Parties, over 90 have concluded safeguards agreements with the IAEA. The Twelve member states of the European Union are parties to the Treaty. All five acknowledged nuclear-weapon states are now parties to the Treaty, since France and China signed in 1992. In 1991 South Africa became the first state which has admitted developing a nuclear weapons programme to accede to the Treaty, as a non-nuclear weapon State. The most notable non-parties include Algeria, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Cuba, India, Israel and Pakistan. Of these, India has carried out a nuclear test, in 1974. Of the states of the former Soviet Union, Kazakhstan and Ukraine, which still retain nuclear weapons, have committed themselves to accession to the NPT as non-nuclear-weapon states as soon as possible.

During the last Irish Presidency of the EC, the European Council adopted a Declaration on Nuclear Non-Proliferation at its meeting in Dublin on 25-26 June 1990. This was the first common declaration on non-proliferation by the Twelve.

MainHeading.P: Ireland, together with its partners in the European Union, is also a member of the Nuclear Suppliers Group which is designed to control exports of nuclear materials and technology, particularly to non-parties to the NPT. We are also members of the Missile Technology Control Regime, which controls exports relating to missile technology, which could be used in the delivery of weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear weapons.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cultural Relations Committee.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs
Qst.hpid: Ms F. Fitzgerald Ms F. Fitzgerald
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs
Qst.Quest: the role of the Cultural Relations Committee of his Department; and its current budget and priorities for this year.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring) Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring)
Speaker.P: The Cultural Relations Committee is an expert body of leading figures in Irish cultural life appointed to advise the Minister for Foreign Affairs on the merits of Irish artistic and cultural projects to be undertaken abroad and to recommend whether or not such projects should be assisted from the annual allocation for cultural relations, which in 1993 is £213,000.

I have approved already this year more than 250 recommendations by the committee which cover the whole spectrum of cultural activity in theatre and dance, music, the visual arts and literature. I am convinced of the value of these projects in creating new outlets for Irish cultural expression and in enhancing the image of Ireland abroad. I note with particular interest a significant number of projects in Eastern Europe, the Far East and South America, as I believe that through increased cultural activity it is possible to develop and expand relations with countries with which we have had little contact in the past.
The committee have furthermore recently recommended financial support in a number of priority areas:

MainHeading.P: — Visual Arts: This year, for the first time in some 30 years, Ireland was represented at the Venice Biennale. I have recently endorsed a proposal from the CRC that in future Ireland participate in other major international art exhibitions and fairs to create a greater awareness internationally of the exciting work currently being undertaken in the visual arts here and to develop new outlets for Irish artists.

—Film: One of the barriers to bringing Irish cinema to foreign audiences is the lack of availability of prints. The Cultural Relations Committee has, accordingly, adopted an ongoing programme, in co-operation with the Irish Film Institute, to purchase prints of Irish films for screening at festivals abroad.

— Literature: To create new markets for Irish literature, particularly on the continent of Europe, the CRC has given its support to the establishment of the Ireland-International Literature Agency which will promote the translation of writing in both English and Irish and the publication of contemporary Irish literature abroad. The Agency, which will be based in the Irish Writers Centre, will, I understand, will be in operation early next year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Revenue Commissioners that the total number of intoxicating liquor licences (including publicans licences, manufacturers licences, dealers licences etc.) issued by Customs and Excise in the calendar years in question are as follows:

MainHeading.P: It should be noted that the licensing year for the main intoxicating liquor licences runs from 1 October to the following 30 September and that those who applied for Spirits Retailer's On-Licences (Publican's Licences), Spirits Retailer's Off-Licences and Wine Retailer's Licences in the 1992-93 licensing year were required, under the provisions of the 1992 Finance Act, to have obtained a tax clearance certificate from the office of the Collector-General before they could renew their licences. Because many of those who applied for tax clearance post-October, 1992 were initially unsuccessful (because their tax affairs were not in order) but subsequently were successful in 1993, there is a marked reduction in the figure shown for the 1992 calendar year when compared with figures quoted for previous calendar years. As regards tax clearance, the Revenue Commissioners estimate that about 13,800 out of the 15,598 licences issued in 1991 would require tax clearance for renewal. I should also mention that in relation to tax clearance that the Collector-General's Office is prepared to meet with publicans who are in arrears and who are prepared to make realistic efforts to discharge those arrears over a reasonable period of time. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tax Incentives.

Qst.hpid: Ms F. Fitzgerald Ms F. Fitzgerald
Qst.Quest: if he will have arrangements made to examine the situation in relation to historic houses and taxation relief in this country; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Ms F. Fitzgerald Ms F. Fitzgerald
Qst.Quest: if he will give tax incentives to owners of listed buildings to continue to maintain them.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 30 and 31 together.
The tax code already has a number of tax reliefs to encourage the preservation of heritage property. These reliefs are as follows:
(1) Section 19, Finance Act, 1982

Section 19, Finance Act, 1982 provides for relief from income tax or corporation tax to owner/occupiers of approved buildings in the State in respect of certain expenditure incurred by them after 5 April, 1982 on the repair, maintenance or restoration of buildings (or of any land occupied or enjoyed with an approved building as part of its garden or grounds of an ornamental nature in respect of which determination have been made——
*by the Commissioners of Public Works in Ireland that it is a building which is intrinsically of significant scientific, historical, architectural or aesthetic interest, and
*by the Revenue Commissioners that reasonable access is afforded to the public.
(2) Section 29, Finance Act, 1992

Section 19, Finance Act, 1982 was recently extended by the provisions of section 29, Finance Act, 1993 to provide tax relief on expenditure incurred on the maintenance or restoration of gardens which are not attached to significant buildings but which are determined by the Commissioners of Public Works to be of significant horticultural, scientific, historical or aesthetic interest. The rules for granting relief under section 29, Finance Act, 1993 are the same as those for section 19, Finance Act, 1982 and the Revenue Commissioners are also empowered to make determinations in respect of reasonable access.
(3) Residential Property Tax

MainHeading.P: In addition to granting tax relief on expenditure incurred on the repair, maintenance or restoration of a building, a determination under section 19, Finance Act, 1982 also removes the building from the charge to residential property tax (section 95, Finance Act, 1983).
(4) Section 4, Finance Act, 1989

Section 4, Finance Act, 1989 provides for relief for heritage houses in designated areas as part of the urban renewal reliefs. The section provides for relief from income tax in relation to houses in designated areas which are determined by the Commissioners of Public Works to be of scientific, historical, architectural or aesthetic significance. The relief consists of an income tax deduction in respect of 25 per cent of the relevant expenditure incurred by an individual in the first year of claim with a further deduction of 5 per cent allowable in each of the following five years, i.e. a total of 50 per cent. The expenditure must be in respect of repair, restoration or maintenance which is consistent with the original character or fabric of the building and the house must be used by the individual as his sole or main residence. As this relief is part of the urban renewal reliefs, it is due to terminate with the other such reliefs on 31 July, 1994.
(5) Section 39, Capital Acquisitions Tax Act, 1976

Section 39, Finance Act, 1978 provides that certain heritage houses and gardens situated in the State are exempt from capital acquisitions tax provided that they are not sold within six years from the valuation date.
The requirements for exemptions are
*the house or garden must not be held for the purposes of trading and must be shown to the satisfaction of the Revenue Commissioners to be of national, scientific, historic or artistic interest,
*reasonable facilities for viewing must be allowed to members of the public on a continuous basis and also for the three years immediately prior to the acquisition.
In view of this range of tax reliefs in relation to heritage property, I have no plans to introduce further incentives in this area.

Qst.Quest: if he will ensure the implementation of the recommendation of the Second Commission on the Status of Women in relation to the carers allowance that the means of the person being cared for should be assessed rather than the means of the carer.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The carer's allowance, which I introduced in 1990, provided, for the first time, for the payment of a weekly allowance directly to a person providing fulltime care and attention to an elderly or incapacitated person. Some 4,600 carers are in receipt of the allowance.

Since its introduction, the carer's allowance has been increased and improved each year. From July last the rate was increased by £6.20 to £59.20 a week. This substantial increase of 11.7 per cent brings the rate into line with the rate of long term social assistance payments.

The carer's allowance scheme is currently under review and the recommendation of the Second Committee on the Status of Women that the means test should be based on the means of the person being cared for rather than on the means of the carer will be considered in that context. I should mention, however, that any change in the present means-testing arrangements would have financial implications which could only be considered in the light of available resources.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Civilianisation in the Garda Síochána.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: the procedures to be adopted for the filling by civilians of senior management posts in the Garda Síochána.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn) Máire Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 36 and 37 together.

I would refer the Deputy to my reply to his supplementary question on civilianisation in the Garda Síochána which I answered recently in the Dáil (Ref: Dáil Debates, 14 October 1993, Columns 1243-1244).

I can confirm that the Commissioner has identified in his corporate strategy plan four posts at managerial level which could be civilianised. These are a personnel officer, a press officer, a management accountant and a head of organisation and development.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the aspects of tourism policy for which he has official responsibility to Dáil Éireann; and those aspects of policy which are a matter for Bord Fáilte and for which he disclaims official responsibility to Dáil Éireann.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Trade (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Trade (Mr. McCreevy)
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to the reply I gave to his previous, similar question on 30 June last, which is as follows:

As Minister for Tourism and Trade I have responsibility for national tourism policy including identifying development priorities, and for monitoring the implementation of tourism policy. I also seek to influence other aspects of public policy which are the responsibility of Government colleagues for the benefit of tourism development.

My specific powers are set out in the Tourist Traffic Acts, 1931-1987, and relate mainly to policy matters specifically concerning the development of Irish tourism. My statutory powers include the provision of grant-in-aid to Bord Fáilte for the development and promotion of tourist traffic, appointment of board members, etc. I am also responsible to the Dáil for the provision of an annual grant-in-aid to CERT and SFADCo in respect of tourism traffic promotion.

However, day to day business of Bord Fáilte, CERT and SFADCo including grant approvals, registration of individual premises and operators, details of expenditure, etc., are matters for the relevant boards, or council in the case of CERT, in accordance with statute and/or memoranda and articles of association.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor)

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Transport to Sheltered Workshops.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the lack of a transport service to sheltered workshops for handicapped adults; and if he will make a provision for the transport of handicapped adults to and from sheltered workshops on the same basis as those under 18 years of age.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The provision of transport to sheltered workshops is primarily a matter for the workshops. In many instances workshops provide transport by means of mini bus service.

People attending workshops would normally qualify for free public transport. In areas where no public transport exists or where persons are unable, because of their disabilities, to avail of public transport health boards generally provide assistance towards transport costs to community workshops — usually the equivalent value of a monthly commuter ticket — currently £44 per month. In the Eastern Health Board a monthly allowance of £11 per person is also available where a person with a disability has to travel approximately 1.5 miles from a local railway station to a community workshop.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sheltered Workshop Participants' Wages.

Qst.Quest: if he will introduce a minimum wage for people with mental or physical handicap who are employed in sheltered workshops in view of the low level of payments currently being made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: At present people in sheltered workshops receive their disability or other allowance of approximately £60 per week plus an additional workshop payment of, on average, between £15 and £20 per week giving a total of up to £80 per week take-home pay. In addition they continue to receive the benefits associated with their allowance such as free travel, free electricity allowance, free telephone rental allowance and a fuel allowance and are usually entitled to free health services.

There would be considerable difficulties in introducing a minimum wage level given the wide range of activities pursued and varying productivity levels of sheltered workers. There would also be significant cost implications. However, I recognise the need for a more structured system of sheltered employment, including payments for people with disabilities. I would hope to have this matter examined in the near future.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Hospital Intern Staff Wages.

Qst.Quest: if he will give the amount of an Irish hospital intern's salary in comparison to other European member states; if there is any proposal to improve interns' salary; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if his attention has been drawn to the fact that intern medical staff working in Irish hospitals are among the worst paid in Europe; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 67 and 68.

The present basic rate of salary for a 39-hour week for a hospital intern is £13,603 per annum. Generally, interns are also paid a living out allowance of £1,355 per annum and are rostered to work a 65 hour week, for which they are paid overtime. The average salary for an intern therefore is, in excess of £22.000 per annum.

MainHeading.P: Intern salaries attract the increases agreed under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress. There are no proposals with my Department for any further salary increases for interns.

Although the internship year forms part of the postgraduate training process, its main aim is to qualify medical graduates for full registration with the Medical Council. As postgraduate training systems vary considerably between some European member states and Ireland, comparisons of salaries between both are not valid.

Qst.Quest: the progress and success, if any, of the job sharing scheme for teachers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.Quest: the post-primary schools in County Donegal without sports halls; and if there are any plans to provide these schools with such necessary facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Physical education facilities are available in all but nine of the 24 post primary schools in County Donegal.

Due to demands on the capital resources available, priority has been given for some time to the provision of essential teaching spaces. As a result, it is not possible to make funding available at this stage for the provision of physical education facilities at all post primary schools. However, physical education facilities are provided in all major new school developments.

The provision of indoor sports accommodation in existing schools, in the form of a general purpose area at primary level and a hall at secondary level will resume as soon as pressure on available resources for urgent classroom accommodation has eased. In the meantime, additional emphasis is being placed on the adjacent siting and common use of school and community recreational facilities and schools should make maximum use of other sports facilities in their area.

Qst.Quest: if she will give details of any surveys or research carried out by her Department to ascertain the extent of dyslexia in this country; and if she will consider organising and funding in-service courses for teachers to enable them to deal with such a learning disability.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: As I advised the House on 6 October last, my Department, in conjunction with the Education Research Centre in Drumcondra, Dublin, conducted a survey of 11-year old and fifth class pupils in May 1993 to establish their reading attainment levels and to monitor trends in reading achievement over time. Pupils with low levels of achievement in reading were a specific focus of the survey. The data gathered is being analysed at present and I expect that the findings will be submitted to me in due course.

In addition, a survey aimed at identifying the extent of disability in ordinary national schools, including difficulties associated with reading, was undertaken by the Special Education Review Committee in 1992. This survey had the purpose of informing the committee in recommending what additional support services are required to meet the education needs of the children in question. Among the surveys findings was that an estimated 1,744 children with specific learning disability, including reading disability, were attending ordinary national schools.

In relation to teacher training, the position is that teachers are trained as a normal part of their teacher training course to identify specific learning disability and indeed a variety of other reading problems. Also, in-service training for remedial teachers is provided on an on-going basis at six centres throughout the country. Teachers who are not in recognised remedial posts are accommodated, where possible, on some of these courses.

Qst.Quest: the number of primary schools in the country without the services of a remedial teacher.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware, I announced earlier this year the appointment of an additional 86 remedial teachers, bringing the total number now in place to 1,033. Remedial teacher posts are allocated on the basis of priority of need and, as a result of this latest allocation of posts, 77 per cent of all primary school pupils now have access to a remedial service. Of the total of 3,209 ordinary primary schools, approximately 1,700 currently have access to the service.

I will be keeping the question of further appointments in this area under regular review as part of a broader commitment to provide a substantial number of additional remedial teachers in coming years.

Qst.Quest: the number of children that can be allowed to travel, properly insured, on a 52 seater bus.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: In order to respond to the Deputy's question, it is necessary to distinguish between vehicles used solely for school transport purposes and those which have additional wider uses.

Fifty-two seater buses used solely for school transport purposes are licensed under Article 60 of the Road Traffic (Public Service Vehicles) Regulations, 1963 and the legal carrying capacity of such vehicles is specified on the actual licence issued by the Garda.

The majority of vehicles used for school transport purposes are also licensed for more general uses under Article 80 of the Road Traffic (Construction, Equipment and Use of Vehicle) Regulations, 1963 as amended by Article 2 of S.I. 273 of 1967. Under these regulations, the vehicles in question, while engaged for school transport purposes, may carry 3 pupils for every authorised 2 seats. Hence, a 52 seater vehicle falling into this category may carry up to 78 school-going children.

Qst.Quest: the number of new national schools that have been built in the past four years; and the number of these built in County Monaghan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Approximately 140 major building projects, being new school or major extensions have been completed or have commenced construction in the last four years. These include three projects in County Monaghan, namely Annyalla, Ballybay and Doohamlet.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the limited range of textbooks through the medium of Irish, she will ensure that there is a broader range of material to provide for the growing number of children who are attending all-Irish schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: With reference to the junior certificate, the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment has provided new syllabuses in most subjects and An Gum, the publications branch of my Department has published the relevant textbooks in Irish. The NCCA are preparing syllabuses for the remaining subjects and textbooks in Irish will be published subsequently.

The NCCA is currently re-examining the primary curriculum and also the structure and curriculum for the senior level in the post-primary schools. The publications branch of my Department will produce the relevant textbooks in the Irish language as these new syllabuses come on stream.
I am aware of the growing demand for textbooks for all Irish schools. The publications branch of my Department will make every effort to meet this demand within the resources available to it.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drugs Awareness Programme.

Qst.Quest: if she has been requested to provide matching funding for a drugs awareness programme part-funded by the EC and the Catholic Social Service Conference; her views on whether this is an important and necessary Leader Training Project; and if she will give a positive response to the request for part-funding.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Application has been made to my Department by the Catholic Social Service Conference for a grant towards the cost of a project on drug abuse prevention to be partly funded by the EC.
I consider that the educational system can make a significant contribution to the overall national strategy on drug abuse.

My Department is represented on the Government's Co-ordinating Committee on Drug Misuse and contributes to the development of the national strategy to prevent such misuse. As a result of the work of this committee, initiatives are kept under review and new initiatives planned.

There is a close liaison between my Department and the Department of Health in order to support schools in the introduction of educational programmes on substance abuse. These programmes deal with abuse of all drugs, including solvents, alcohol and tobacco. All schools, both primary and post-primary, and third level colleges, have been provided with information on the abuse of substances.

MainHeading.P: A major pilot project on substance abuse has taken place over the past two years focused on post-primary schools. This project was carried out with the Department of Health and the Mater Dei Counselling Centre, Clonliffe Road, Dublin and with support from the EC. The outcome of this project, including Educational Resource Materials, are being disseminated to all post primary schools during the current school year. A programme of inservice training for teachers will be included with the dissemination.

My Department co-operates, as well, with the Regional Health Boards and with voluntary agencies such as Youth Organisations and Parent Groups in initiatives aimed at alerting young people to the dangers of substance abuse. In all projects undertaken, schools and teachers are advised to consult with parents and to inform them of the educational activities in schools.
As available funding is fully committed, my Department is not in a position to grant-aid the particular project planned by the Catholic Social Service Conference.

Qst.Quest: the position regarding the proposed Community College at Caherciveen, County Kerry; if she will endeavour to advance the project to development stage 2; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Following discussions with the County Kerry vocational education committee, the accommodation requirements of the proposed new Community College have been reviewed and a revised schedule of accommodation will shortly be forwarded to the vocational education committee for its agreement. Arrangements will be made with the vocational education committee for architectural planning to proceed as quickly as possible.

Qst.Quest: the position relating to the construction of a new national school at Faha, Killarney, County Kerry; whether she will ensure that provision is made for this project in her Department's Estimate for 1994; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The preparation of tender documents has been completed for this project. Because of other demands deemed to be of a higher priority which had to take precedence it was not possible to include this project in the national schools capital programme for 1993. It will be considered for inclusion in the 1994 building programme in the light of other commitments and priorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Adult Education Courses.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the low participation levels in some areas of Dublin in adult education courses offered by the City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee; if she will request her officials to review matters in consultation with the committee; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Over 17,000 adults participated in part-time adult education courses in the City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee area in 1992-93, involving almost 350 courses.

I understand that there are low participation rates in general adult education courses in some areas where there are a high number of disadvantaged people. The vocational education committee encourages participation in adult education in these areas through special interventions and programmes which include the following:
—Assistance with fees for attendance at general part-time courses for adults.

—Under the Adult Literacy and Community Education Scheme, the vocational education committee funds 11 literacy schemes in the city and 53 voluntary groups engaged in community adult education activities.

MainHeading.P: —Over 1,000 long term unemployed adults are engaged at present in fulltime education in the Vocational Training Opportunities scheme and under the Department of Social Welfare second level scheme for the long term unemployed.
—Over 350 young adults who left school without qualification undergo specially designed education programmes under the Youthreach scheme.
—A large number of young adults receive tuition in numeracy and literacy in Community Training Workshops and Travellers Workshops.

My Department is in regular contact with the City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee concerning various aspects of adult education and it provided substantially increased funding to the vocational education committee this year for the special interventions indicated above.

Qst.Quest: whether there are any funds at her disposal either through the national lottery or otherwise, whereby she can make a grant or award available to St. Mary's Brass and Reed Band, Maynooth, County Kildare in view of the band's ongoing developmental needs, its cultural and historic links and its need to upgrade and improve its premises; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I regret that there are no funds at the disposal of my Department from which a grant could be made towards the band in question.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Materials in School Buildings.

Qst.hpid: Ms F. Fitzgerald Ms F. Fitzgerald
Qst.Quest: if she has satisfied herself with the use of materials currently used in school buildings; her views on the serious deterioration of many school buildings; and the plans, if any, she has to ensure that similar problems will not recur in the building of new schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware that despite very substantial investment in school buildings over the years, much of which was needed to cater for increased enrolment, the condition of some schools leaves much to be desired. In recognition of this the Programme for Government (1992) states:
“We will allocate an increased amount in each of the next five years to implement a planned programme of replacing or refurbishing sub-standard school buildings”.

However, I would like to assure the Deputy that my Department is satisfied that the procedures governing the choice of materials and the supervision of construction are satisfactory. These procedures are regularly reviewed and updated to ensure that the materials used in school buildings comply with all relevant Irish and European standards and codes of practice.
